Migration Research Journal

Daily observations and discoveries from our butterfly migration research team

Peak Migration Season

Fall migration is at its peak! Our research team is documenting unprecedented numbers of Monarch butterflies. Latest count: 2,847 tagged butterflies in the past 48 hours.

Migration Patterns

Monarch Butterfly Mass Migration Event - Day 3 Observations

October 15, 2024 by Dr. Sarah Chen

Extraordinary numbers continue to pass through our research station. Today we documented 1,247 individual monarchs between 9 AM and 4 PM, with peak activity occurring around 1:30 PM when wind conditions were optimal.

Butterflies were counted using standardized transect walks every 2 hours. Each individual was photographed for wing pattern analysis and GPS coordinates were recorded. Weather conditions: Clear skies, 72°F, wind 5-8 mph from the southwest.

Monarch Migration Field Study
Behavioral Studies

Feeding Behavior Analysis in Painted Lady Butterflies

October 12, 2024 by Dr. Michael Rodriguez

Our study of nectar feeding preferences in Vanessa cardui reveals fascinating insights into plant selection during migration. Over 72 hours of observation, we documented preferred flower species and feeding duration.

Painted Lady Behavior Nectar
Climate Impact

Temperature Effects on Migration Timing: 5-Year Analysis

October 10, 2024 by Dr. Emma Thompson

Climate change is shifting migration patterns significantly. Our 5-year dataset shows fall migration now begins an average of 8 days later than in 2019, with peak activity dates shifting correspondingly.

Early Period (2019-2021): Migration peak typically occurred between September 20-25. Average temperature during peak: 65°F. Consistent patterns with historical data.

Recent Period (2022-2024): Migration peak now occurs between September 28-October 3. Average temperature during peak: 68°F. Notable shift in timing correlates with extended warm periods.

Climate Long-term Study Data Analysis

Recent Field Observations

Live updates from our research team in the field

Field Observation Updates

  • Live Update 2 hours ago

    Unusual Swallowtail Activity

    Large group of Eastern Tiger Swallowtails observed at research station 3. Approximately 40 individuals feeding on joe-pye weed. This is unusual behavior for October.

    Location: North Trail, Station 3
  • Weather Alert 4 hours ago

    Strong Winds Affecting Migration

    Wind speeds of 15-20 mph from the north are causing monarchs to seek shelter. Migration activity reduced by approximately 70% from normal levels.

    All stations reporting
  • Research Note 6 hours ago

    New Species Documented

    First confirmed sighting of Variegated Fritillary (Euptoieta claudia) at our research site. Individual was photographed and documented at the native plant garden.

    Documented by: Dr. Sarah Chen
  • Equipment 8 hours ago

    Weather Station Calibration

    All weather monitoring equipment has been recalibrated. Temperature and wind measurements now show improved accuracy for migration correlation studies.

    Maintenance: Technical Team
